awd_titl_txt: New Directions in Partially Hyperbolic Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to gain a deeper understanding of chaotic dynamical systems.  Chaotic dynamics is abundant in the real world and appears throughout sciences and engineering.  It can appear in simple mechanical mechanisms such as a double pendulum or in complicated natural phenomena such as convection currents in the atmosphere.  The study of such naturally arising examples is extremely challenging and we are very far from a good understanding of them.  The partially hyperbolic dynamical systems that will be studied in this project are simplified mathematical models of chaotic dynamical systems that arise in nature.  The emphasis of the project will be on a wide range of problems which are new in the field or have received only marginal attention in the past.  Potentially, this research may have impacts in physics, biology, chemistry, engineering and other areas where chaotic dynamical systems arise.

Anosov and partially hyperbolic diffeomorphisms are the prime examples of chaotic dynamical systems. In the past decades the study of ergodic and chaotic properties in partially hyperbolic dynamics has flourished, while geometric aspects haven't received as much attention.  This will be a wide-ranging program to develop geometric structure theory for partially hyperbolic dynamics.  The program includes: (1) further development of the Anosov bundle theory; (2) development of topological and global structural stability for partially hyperbolic diffeomorphisms; (3) initiation of the smooth conjugacy program for 3-dimensional partially hyperbolic diffeomorphisms.   Further, the project will to bring partially hyperbolic vision beyond the dominated splitting paradigm and take first steps into the realm of homological and coarse hyperbolicity. Finally, the project will expand work on new examples in partially hyperbolic dynamics. New examples have intrinsic value and can be used as additional ground for the structure theory to be applied and tested. The project will use a diverse blend of dynamics and three and higher dimensional topology.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Generally speaking, the project contributed to the study of chaotic dynamical systems also known as hyperbolic dynamical systems. Namely the results of the project shed a lot of new light on the structure of the space of various hyperbolic systems. In particular, several new classes of partially hyperbolic diffeomorphisms were exhibited. This was achieved via development of the surgery (or cut-and-paste) technique adapted to hyperbolic dyanmics. While these techniques were well-established in dimension 3, the PI's work is the first of its kind in higher dimensions.

Jointly with Rodriguez Hertz the PI introduced a new method which allows to understand the structure of smooth conjugacy classes (equivalence classes under smooth coordinate changes) of expanding maps, which are particularly simple chaotic dynamical systems. The underlying mechanism appears to be very robust and it is likely that it will have a lot of success for smooth classification in various hyperbolic settings.

The project also focused on the rigidity program which, in broad terms, seeks to characterize the distinguished nice dynamical system in the space of all dynamical systems via various invariants. 

The PI disseminated the research results via numerous venues including two mini-courses at international conferences. The project contributed to training of junior mathematicians at graduate and post-doctoral level via mentorship and organization of working seminars.
